Exaggerate: The claim that volcanic ash can kill the novel coronavirus exaggerates the effectiveness of volcanic ash as a virus killer.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks scientific evidence to support its assertion that volcanic ash can destroy the new coronavirus.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the low number of COVID-19 cases in the Philippines is solely due to the eruption of the Taal volcano and the presence of volcanic ash.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert's verdict provides an alternative explanation by stating that the low number of cases in the Philippines is not attributed to volcanic ash but rather to other factors.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the statements from health experts, including the WHO and the Philippines health department, who have stated that volcanic ash is hazardous to health and does not have anti-viral properties.
Falters at times: The claim falters by not considering the fact that there is no vaccine or anti-viral medicine to prevent or treat COVID-19, as stated by the WHO.
Understate: There is no evident understatement bias in the provided claim.
